awd_titl_txt: Forming functional surfaces through surface-anchored macromolecular networks
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The design and fabrication of materials with functional and tailorable surface properties represents one of the most important challenges facing current materials research.  It is daunting to identify a material that enables independent control of chemical composition, surface topography, mobility of functional groups, mechanical properties, and charge.  Polymer coatings comprising macromolecules linked at various locations via so-called crosslink points attached to surfaces may fit the bill.  A major obstacle that has hindered widespread application of such materials is the need for chemical synthesis of specialty polymers.  This project overcomes this limitation by turning a wide variety of polymers into surface-anchored crosslinked polymer coatings using a family of simple crosslinker molecules that are either commercially available or are very easy to synthesize.  Thus, anyone can utilize the proposed method in combination with a variety of starting materials to fabricate functional surfaces with controlled composition, softness, surface topography, and other important physico-chemical characteristics.  The processes leading to the formation of such surfaces have been designed to be highly scalable, so that they could be, in principle, applied to coat large-area surfaces.  This research project will also contribute to education of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in science and engineering.  These involve scientific training and communication, presentation skills, as well as ethical principles in science and technology.  Outreach activities in both local venues (high schools and colleges in the Research Triangle area) as well as at elementary school in Ararat, VA (located in one of the most rural areas of our country) will take place.  Local K-12 students and teachers will be encouraged to participate in the research/educational activities through individual mentoring and via programs organized by NC State's Science House.  Current efforts and future plans for organizing scientific and outreach meetings for academe, industry, and general public in the Research Triangle region are included.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The central goal of this project is to create functional surfaces by attaching polymer network films with highly tailorable characteristics onto solid substrates.  These polymer networks comprise arrays of long chain molecules (i.e., macromolecules) connected mutually at several nodes (i.e., crosslink points).  The polymer networks are generated by crosslinking macromolecules using small functional molecules (SFMs) equipped with two functional groups, A and B, wherein A forms a chemical bond with a neighboring polymer chain, and B groups from two neighboring SFMs (or/and the substrate) form either a chemical or a physical bond, depending on the nature of the B units.  This method makes any polymer, regardless of its functionality, amenable to chemical crosslinking and immobilization on surfaces.  Importantly, the SFMs are either available commercially or can be readily synthesized.  The immediate scientific and technological impact lies in providing a source-agnostic framework to design and produce surfaces with controlled chemical composition, tuned (and erasable) topology, tailorable softness and friction, and other relevant physico-chemical interfacial characteristics.  The simplicity and tunablity of the network-forming process makes it ideal for scientists and engineers without requiring high chemical expertise, and broadens its scope to biomedical and healthcare sciences, security, or national defense.  The project description outlines tasks that aim at testing the proposed hypothesis of network generation and establishing structure-process properties.  Specifically, the structure and kinetics of network formation will be established for a series of different SFMs, different annealing times, and annealing temperatures.  Functional polymer network coatings that alter mechanical properties of topography in response to external magnetic fields will be generated by incorporating magnetically-responsive nanoparticles into the SFMs.  The proposed effort also outlines new ways of forming bilayers featuring hydrogels (i.e., polymer networks that swell in water) and silicone elastomers (i.e., flexible rubbers that do not require solvent to remain flexible).  These laminates are frequently used in biomedical, shape-changing, and deformable materials, yet their preparation currently relies on harsh physical treatment of the elastomer component.  The proposed methodology removes this limitation and enables novel, cleaner, and reproducible manufacturing of these important composite materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Polymer network coatings have gained considerable attention due to their application in tissue engineering, antifouling coatings, catalysis, tribology, and many applications. A few techniques form such macromolecular structures. One involves “grafting from” polymerization followed by crosslinking the macromolecular grafts. Another method uses polymers containing cross-linkable units. Applying heat or UV light forms the gels and anchors them to the substrate.

              The main goal of this project was to develop general strategies for generating surface-anchored macromolecular networks using commercially available small-molecule gelators. We wanted to apply this procedure to various polymers without specialized polymer synthesis. We utilized organosilanes with a siloxane headgroup and sulfonyl azide tail group. These two end units were connected with either a “neutral” methylene linker or a phenyl-based group. The sulfonyl azide group reacts with C-H bonds in the polymer while the siloxane groups condense, completing the crosslink formation. The siloxane headgroup can anchor the network to particular substrates (i.e., oxides). Both reactions are activated by heat or UV-triggered heat processes. We tested the procedure using several polymers and formed networks on flat silica surfaces and commercial hydrophobic elastomers.

              The network density, represented by the gel fraction, Pgel, i.e., a fraction of macromolecules incorporated into the network relative to the initial number of polymers, can be adjusted by controlling the number of activated sulfonyl azide groups, which, in turn, depends on the initial concentration of the gelators, annealing temperature, and time. Pgel can thus be “dialed in” by independently varying the abovementioned parameters. Inspired by the well-known “time-temperature superposition”, we sought to establish a “time-temperature-concentration” superposition. We tested this protocol by forming gels on flat silica substrates using poly(vinyl pyridine) (PVP). Networks formed at various temperatures, various concentrations of 6-azido sulfonyl hexyl triethoxysilane (6-ASHTES) in the PVP/6-ASHTES mixture, and annealing time all exhibited different Pgel values. For each temperature, we expected Pgel to attain a unique value when plotted as a function of the number of activated 6-ASHTES molecules relative to the total number of VP units. We superimposed the data onto unique master curves by shifting the Pgel data horizontally along the 6-ASHTES/VP axis. We related the needed shift factors to the fraction of the activated 6-ASHTES molecules. Kinetic Monte Carlo simulations exhibited the same qualitative trends as the experimental data and collapsed onto a master curve when adopting the same normalization shifts. While 6-ASHTES can only be activated thermally, we established that 4-azidosulfonyl phenethyl trimethoxysilane (4-ASPTMS) could be activated both by heat and relatively mild UV light (254 nm). Because these processes are orthogonal, one can use the same gelator (i.e., 4-ASPTMS) to form gels using two independent triggers. We capitalized on this observation by creating orthogonal gels activated by heat in one direction and UV light in an orthogonal direction. These combinatorial libraries provided fast screening on how Pgel depends on the degree of activation of the gelator.

              In addition to silica surfaces, we formed hydrogel networks on top of elastomer substrates. The motivation was to use flexible substrates that can be readily deformed using mechanical force, further tuning the characteristics of the top hydrogel layer. In one scenario, we developed methods for forming PVP gels on top of elastomer supports. The PVP gel was further decorated with tannic acid. We tested the antibacterial resistance of such composites against gram-positive (S. Aureus) and gram-negative (E. Coli) bacteria. We explored various fabrication strategies for generating such laminates: depositing the tanning acid on the elastomer/hydrogel laminate at rest, pre-stretched elastomer/hydrogel laminates; pre-stretched laminates and deposited hydrogel, and then adding tanning acid. The final antibacterial resistance varied among the various sample fabrication strategies. The last and most challenging task was to develop methods for adhering performed hydrogel layers to elastomers. Elastomers are inherently hydrophobic and possess weak adhesion. Avoiding the conventional physical treatment of the elastomers (e.g., plasma or UV/ozone), we conceived and tested elastomer modification using 4-ASPTMS that enabled anchoring the hydrogels. We tested the approach using a variety of commercial elastomers and hydrogel networks.

Simplicity, versatility, use of commercial materials, and potential scalability make the technique a method of choice for many non-chemists who need to produce functional coatings. The project helped establish conditions leading to the manufacture of coatings with controlled composition, softness, surface topography, and other critical physicochemical characteristics on the application side. Connecting commercial elastomers to hydrogel layers will provide many materials communities to create functional layers that could be employed in numerous applications.
